p.seg: Every time the puppies of that dog faced the room, they barked incessantly. The family was alarmed
and told the head of the household, "Kill this dog!" Although they repeatedly warned him, he still did not kill it. Around the second and third months,
when preparing the annual rice pounding, the woman of the house went to the rice pounding area with snacks for the rice-pounding women.
As she entered the mortar, the dog bit her clothes and chased her, barking. She became terrified and transformed into a jackal and fled.
and stayed there. The head of the household, seeing this, said, "You were born from my middle son, so I haven't forgotten and always come
to sleep with you." Therefore, he came because he recited the husband's words, so his name is *Kito*. At that time, his wife wore a red-dyed skirt
(now called a peach blossom skirt), elegant and beautiful. The hem of the skirt trailed away. The husband, watching her departing figure, sang a love song: *Kobi wa minaka, wa ube ni ochi;*
*Nuta makachiru haroka ni, miete irushiko yue ni.* Therefore, the name of their child born from that union was *Nagato no Kito*. Also, that child's
surname was *Hefuri*. This person was very strong and had much power, running as swift as a bird's flight.
He is the origin of the *Mitsuno no Kuni Kitsune* etc.

得電之令生子強力在縁. The third [story]:
Long ago, during the reign of Emperor Mǐndá (his name was *Iware no Mikado no Miya Kuni, Tomena no Kuratama Shiki no Mikoto*), in Owari Province, Aguchi District, Kata
Village, there was a man who was working in the fields. Because there was a light rain, he stood
under a tree holding a gold staff. Then, lightning struck. Immediately, terrified, he clutched the gold staff and stood there. Then, lightning fell in front of
the man, turning into a small child. And when the man tried to strike the child with the gold staff, the lightning spoke, "Don't harm me!
I will repay your kindness." The man asked, "How will you repay me?" The lightning answered, "I will reside in you
and become a fetus to repay you. Therefore, make a *kusu* (camphor) boat for me and set it in the water, floating bamboo leaves, and give it to me."
Immediately, he prepared it as the lightning said and gave it to him. Then the lightning said, "Don't come near! Keep far away!" Immediately,
he ascended to heaven in a loving mist. Afterwards, the child born had snakes wrapped twice around its head, with the tails riding behind, when born.
When he was ten years old or more, the court heard about his power and thought it was genuine. He came to
reside near the palace. At that time, there was a temporary King of Strength. He was living in a separate
residence in the northeastern corner of the palace. In that northeastern corner, there was an eight-foot square stone. The King of Strength went out from his own house and took that stone
and threw it. Then he closed the doors to his residence, not allowing others to enter or exit. The young child watched and thought, "The famous
strongman is that person." At night, when no one was watching, he took the stone and threw it one foot farther. The King of Strength saw
this, took the stone in his hand, and threw it, but he could not throw it any farther than usual. The young child also threw it two feet
farther. The King, seeing this, threw it twice, but still couldn't throw it farther. The young child stood at the spot where he threw the stone. The young child's footprint
sank three inches deep. The stone was also thrown three feet farther. The King, seeing the footprint, thought, "This is where the young child
threw the stone from, I will throw the stone where he relied on". And was about to throw but the child fled, The king chases after the child and the child flees passing through the wall
and the child is also coming back, the king climbs over the wall and gives chase and the child passed outside.
Having a thief return a silk robe: a vow miraculously manifesting a Bodhisattva's cultivation resulting in the karmic connection of the silk robe. Chapter Thirty-Four.
A wise person commissions the painting of a Buddha statue for the Four Graces, resulting in a karmic connection where miraculous signs are verified. Chapter Thirty-Five.
The karmic connection of catching lightning. Chapter One.
A man of the Shǎo shī tribe named Qī Qīng. In the 23rd year of the reign of Emperor Yūryaku (also called Emperor Ohodo) of the Asakura Palace in Hatsuse, he ruled the world with heroic strategies.
He served as an attendant to Emperor Yūryaku (also called Emperor Wakayamatakeru). When the Emperor resided in the Iware Palace, the Emperor
and the Empress were in the Celestial Peace Hall together. Qī Qīng was then summoned and commanded, "You should be ashamed for not being able to invoke thunder!"
He replied, "I shall invoke it." The Emperor commanded, "Then you should invoke it!" Qī Qīng obeyed the imperial order and left the palace.
Wearing a red-flagged helmet and riding a horse, he went from the path in front of Abe Satayama
to the road in front of Toyoura Temple. Arriving at Qī Qīng's various mountain passes, he shouted in a whisper, "Heaven!
Thunder and Lightning Gods! The Emperor respectfully requests your presence!" However, returning on horseback, he said, "Although you are a Lightning
God, why do you not heed the Emperor's request?" As he rode back, lightning struck at Toyoura Temple and Iioaka.
Qī Qīng saw it and called the priests, entered a cage, and carried it towards the great palace.
He reported to the Emperor, "The Lightning God has been invoked!" At that moment, the lightning emitted a bright light. The Emperor, seeing it, was afraid
and presented silk.
He ordered that the place where the lightning fell be returned to. It is now called Lightning Hill (located north of the former capital's Ta'momiya). After that, Qī Qīng died.
The Emperor decreed that mourning be observed for seven days and seven nights, praising his loyalty. A tomb was built at the place where the lightning struck. A permanent
inscribed stone pillar was erected, saying, "This is the tomb of Qī Qīng, who captured the lightning." This lightning harbored resentment and struck.
It struck the stone pillar. The lightning was captured in the gaps of that pillar. The Emperor, hearing this, released the lightning and it did not
die. The thunder remained for seven days and seven nights. The Emperor ordered messengers to say to the stone pillar, "The life of
the dead Qī Qīng is capturing the lightning." This is the origin of the ancient name "Lightning Hill."

The karmic connection of a fox becoming a wife and bearing children. Chapter Two.
Long ago, during the reign of Emperor Qīnmíng (Isokishima no Kanazaki no Miya of Heavenly Country Oshihirakihiro Niwa), a man from Ōnogōri in Mino Province, named Yīng,
sought a good wife and went on a journey. In the wilderness, he encountered a young woman. The woman
was beautiful. He inquired, "Where are you going, young maiden?" She replied, "I am going to seek a husband."
Yīng also said, "Will you become my wife?" The woman agreed and replied. He immediately took her to his house.
They lived together and she became pregnant and gave birth to a son. At that time, his family dog gave birth to puppies on the fifteenth day of the twelfth month.

Śhōtoku Taishi's Manifestation of Miraculous Signs, Chapter Four.
Śhōtoku Taishi was the child of Emperor Tachibana no Toyohi who ruled at the Kanomiya Palace by the Pond.
The Emperor who ruled at the Oharida Palace established him as Crown Prince. Again, he had three names.
One was Umayado Toyomimi, the second was Śhōtoku, and the third was Uetsumiya.
Because he was born at Umayado, he was called Umayado. He was born with innate wisdom; when ten people pleaded their cases at once,
he could hear and distinguish everything without missing a single word, so he was called Toyosatomimi. His deportment resembled that of a monk in his conduct.
He elaborately composed commentaries on the *Śrīmālādevī Sūtra*, the *Lotus Sūtra*, etc., broadly benefitting beings, and established ranks based on meritorious deeds and filial piety.
Therefore, he was called Śhōtoku. Because he lived above the Emperor's palace, he was called Uetsumiya no Kōji (Prince of the Upper Palace). The Crown Prince,
when residing at the Okamoto Palace, one time having an opportunity, went out of the palace for sightseeing, a procession, to the roadside in Kataoka Village.
There was a ragged, smelly person lying ill. The Prince saw him, and from below, together
they conversed, asking about things. He took off the clothes he was wearing and covered the sick person before proceeding on his way. The sightseeing having ended,
he returned in his palanquin, proceeding on his way. He hung the clothes he had removed on a tree branch, but the beggar was gone. The Prince took the clothes,
put them on, and a retainer said, "Having touched a lowly person, the clothes are defiled. Why do you wear them again?"
The Prince said, "Leave it. You do not understand this." Later, the ragged, smelly person was elsewhere. The Prince heard of it
and sent a messenger to enshroud him. At the northeast corner of Okamoto Temple was the mountain of the *moribe*, where a tomb was made to bury him. It was named
Yagi no haka (Yagi Tomb). Later, a messenger was sent to build it, but the tomb entrance would not open. There was no way for a person to enter. Only

a song was composed and written to erect at the tomb door. The song said: "(If the hem of my robe at Okaba of Ikaru is wet, I will have you, with your tender arms, sleep together with me.)" The messenger
returned and reported the situation. The Prince heard this but said nothing. He truly knew. A sage knows a sage, a common person does not know a person.
The physical eyes of a commoner see a lowly person, but the all-seeing eyes of a sage see a hidden body. This
is a miraculous thing.

Also, the younger brother of the Dharma Teacher Karu, Kunise-shi, was a teacher from the kingdom of Paekche. He lived at Takamiya Temple in Katsuragi, Yamato Province, Japan. At that time, as a Dharma Teacher, he lived in the North Quarters, and his name was Gankaku. That teacher

always went out into the village in the morning and returned to his quarters in the evening, making this his constant practice. At that time, a disciple of Enzei-shi, a *upasaka*, saw this and told the teacher. The teacher said, "Be silent." The *upasaka*,
secretly broke through the wall of the quarters, and the room emitted light and shone brightly. The *upasaka* saw this and reported it again to the teacher.
The teacher replied, "There is a reason, so I admonish you not to speak." And then Gankaku suddenly ended his life.
At that time, Enzei-shi told the disciple,
the *upasaka*, "Cremate him and collect the ashes." Immediately, he obeyed the teacher's order, cremated him, and collected the ashes. Then that *upasaka*
lived in Ōmi. At that time, someone in Ōmi said, "There is Gankaku-shi here." Immediately, the *upasaka*
went and saw him. It was indeed Gankaku-shi. Meeting the *upasaka*, he spoke, saying,
"For a while, there has been nothing but longing and longing, and I have been unable to rest. You should know that this is a manifestation of the Sage." Eating
the five pungent roots is forbidden in Buddhism, but there is no sin for a sage to eat them.
